title: A New View of the Aftermath of JFK’s Assassination
content:
This is a still frame of a film shot just a few moments after President John F. Kennedy was shot in Dallas, TX in 1963:

From a NY Times story back in September:

For decades Mr. Carpenterâ€™s 8-millimeter snippets of what transpired in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963, have been a family heirloom. When he died in 1991 at 77, the reel, which included footage of his twin boysâ€™ birthday party, passed to his wife, Mabel, then to a daughter, Diana, and finally to a grandson, James Gates.

A family heirloom! I find it fascinating that bits of history like this keep turning up. Whatâ€™s the thought process of the sort of person who keeps (culturally, monetarily, investigatorially?) valuable objects like this casually squirreled away for 60 years? How much more of this kind of thing exists and how much of it just gets thrown away? Again, fascinating!

Another interesting facet is the process of verifying the filmâ€™s authenticity. Iâ€™m sure the auction house did their due diligence, but so did the Times.
